Description: Stopped in today to check out the museum, it is laid out really nice starting with Native American artifacts and then from there onto early settlers. The guy that was there "Brian" was very friendly and knowledgeable. We really enjoyed it.

Great place to visit! They even have a few photo op cars, so take the kids. We showed up at closing, and were not run off. Owner even talked to us and answered any and all questions regarding the racecars.
Dodge City is not the wild wild West town of yore, but a place full of museums, statues and entertainment.  We just dipped our toes in and can’t wait to go back to really get to know the place.

This was a great stop off during a long road trip.  There is a small museum, a few outdoor exhibits, and of course the Half Way sign.  Parking is a breeze, it won't take you very long to see everything, but it's one of those places you will be glad you stopped at when you think back to your trip.  If you can venture to this spot on your way to wherever you should do so.

Address: 201 E Wyatt Earp Blvd, Dodge City
Description: Large Sundial 'hidden' behind the old railroad depot. A pair of them as tall as a flagpole, labeled by timezone.

Address: 488 W Wyatt Earp Blvd, Dodge City
Description: Great stop to see the statues , train , Boot Hill . Fun fun fun !

Place Name: Edwards County Historical Museum and Sod House
Description: To see the sod house up close and in person was amazing ! The historic society lady was super nice and super helpful with knowledge of historic places and explaining the sod house . There is so many things to see !! From artifacts to a petrified mammoth tusk to plow implements and different various pieces of the past its a must see and it's free!! Also the little church is open to walk in and experience.  The big steam locomotive is accessible with stairs to get up to the cab !! Worth a stop and worth the visit !

Address: 201 E Wyatt Earp Blvd, Dodge City
Description: It's a functioning train station, so you can't expect much. Clean though. If the lady at the visitor's center wouldn't have told us, we wouldn't  have found the entrance.
A beautiful mural behind the salsa man
Salsa Man is a great photo op ! We had quiet a few laughs trying to get that perfect shot ! Cool!
What a neat part of history that popped up out of nowhere on a road trip!
It was great! It was beautiful!

When driving down the dirt road,  approaching the round barn, I thought how neat it was that it was in the middle of nowhere. I know that may not make sense, but when you’re living in a large city, small things like this put a smile on my face.

The barn is unattended but is well maintained and operates on the honor system.

Unlatch the barn door and turn the lights on. You can read about its history on the walls located on the first level inside the barn.
No description available

Basically impossible to see the tracks as of early October. However, the surrounding views are gorgeous, with prairie grass waving and very colorful. I wonder if they should put up something to block weather, as it seems like all the Santa Fe track sites I visited are deteriorating. It feels like something could be done to preserve them better. Either way, the site is still in a beautiful spot, just beware of the heavy construction traffic on these roads to the site, I do not recommend taking this highway any further than to this site.

Address: 400 W Wyatt Earp Blvd, Dodge City
Description: Nice historic area. Easy to park and walk to all the statues and train.

Address: 201 E Wyatt Earp Blvd, Dodge City
Description: Large Sundial 'hidden' behind the old railroad depot. A pair of them as tall as a flagpole, labeled by timezone.

Place Name: Fort Dodge Camp Supply Military Road
Description: Interesting large plaque explains the history of the supply camp road.

Address: 500 W Wyatt Earp Blvd, Dodge City
Description: History buffs, we were absolutely thrilled with the museum! The displays are carefully curated and cared for. The information provided is interesting and engaging. Everything is well organized and clean. The staff are all professional and courteous. We enjoyed our visit immensely.

I really loved this. You could walk around the rooms, it wasn’t roped off like a lot of other places. The two ladies there were very friendly and informative. It was fun to learn the history of the house and the families who lived there.
